I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  Following a request from the Government of Bangladesh, the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB)  included  capacity  development  technical  assistance  (TA)  in  the  country  partnership 
strategy midterm review, 2006–2010 for Bangladesh to support climate change mitigation and 
renewable energy development.1 During the consultation mission in November 2010, ADB, the 
Ministry of Environment and Forests, and the Ministry of Power, Energy and Mineral Resources 
(MPEMR) discussed the capacity development needs and identified broad areas of possible 
intervention.  
 
2.  The concept paper was approved on 22 March 2011 and a TA fact-finding mission was 
fielded 3–6 April 2011 to design the content and implementation arrangements of the TA. In a 
letter dated 21 April 2011, the Ministry of Finance confirmed the aide-mémoire containing the 
impact, outcome, outputs, implementation arrangements, cost, financing arrangements, terms of 
reference of consultants, and design and monitoring framework (Appendix 1).2 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  Given  its  geophysical  location,  low  deltaic  flood  plain,  and  erratic  monsoon  rainfall 
Bangladesh  is  vulnerable  to  the  impact  of  climate  change.  Since  1990,  the  country  has 
experienced a rise in sea level, intensified precipitation, and runoff variability—causing massive 
floods in the rainy season and severe drought in the dry season. Further, the country’s large 
population with low gross domestic product per capita ($641 in 2010) makes Bangladesh’s 
economy highly vulnerable to the impacts of climate change. 
 
4.  As of 2005, the energy sector was the largest contributor of carbon dioxide emissions at 
36,071 gigagrams or 56% of the total. As projected by the Asia Least-Cost Greenhouse Gas 
Abatement Strategy study3 using 1990 as the base year, the energy sector’s greenhouse gas 
emissions will increase sevenfold and its percentage contribution to total emissions will increase 
over time up to 2020. This trend implies that the impact of climate change caused by the energy 
sector will intensify. 
 
5.  Meanwhile, only about 47% of the population had access to electricity in 2009, and the 
energy shortage has become the most critical infrastructure constraint to economic growth. In 
2010, the maximum demand for electricity is about 6,454 megawatts (MW) and it is expected to 
rise to 8,349 MW in 2013. However, the maximum available generation is 4,162 MW (of an 
installed capacity of 6,208 MW)—3,170 MW from natural gas and 165 MW from hydropower—
leaving a significant supply gap. The main causes for the supply shortage, among others, are 
(i) poor  operational  efficiency  of  thermal  power  plants  and  inefficient  use  of  energy; 
(ii) inadequate  supply  of  natural  gas,  which  forms  the  main  source  of  primary  energy  for 
electricity generation (80% of generation capacity is based on natural gas); and (iii) lack of 
diversification in energy supply, including inadequate exploitation of renewable energy. As a 
result,  the  country  is  experiencing  long  hours  of  power  interruptions  causing  significant 
economic losses. Many industrial and commercial establishments depend on expensive and 
inefficient captive generation during power interruptions. Therefore, Bangladesh faces the uphill 
task of improving access to electricity and removing power-related constraints for economic

development while maintaining environmental sustainability through a low-carbon growth path in 
the energy sector. 
 
6.  To address the power supply shortage problem as well as to abate greenhouse gas 
emission,  the  National  Energy  Policy,  2004  is  focusing on  (i)  providing  a sustainable  and 
balanced energy supply, (ii) promoting rational use of energy, (iii) improving sector management 
and performance, and (iv) increasing private sector participation and investment. Further, the 
government enacted the Renewable Energy Policy of Bangladesh in 2008. Accordingly, the 
Sustainable Energy Development Authority (SEDA), is being established as a focal point for 
sustainable  energy  development  and  promotion,  with  support  from  German  development 
cooperation through GIZ and the World Bank. Through the Sustainable Energy for Development 
Project, GIZ is supporting the preparation of a SEDA act as well as its organizational formation 
and management mechanism. The World Bank, through its umbrella TA support for Power 
Sector Development, is assisting the development of SEDA’s strategy.  
 
7.  In Strategy 2020,4 ADB has identified energy as a core operational sector, and achieving 
environmental  sustainability  as  a  strategic  priority  in  helping  developing  member  countries 
reduce poverty and improve living conditions and quality of life. ADB’s energy sector strategy in 
Bangladesh  also  emphasizes  promoting  an  enabling  business  environment  and  increased 
investment in clean energy such as wind and solar power, demonstrating a strong and clear 
consistency between the strategic priorities of ADB and Bangladesh in the energy sector.  
 
8.  The TA activities are consistent with the government’s energy policy and ADB’s energy 
sector strategy in Bangladesh. Taking into account ADB’s former intervention and other donors’ 
contribution, the TA will provide key enabling conditions for the effective promotion of renewable 
energy development in Bangladesh. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
9.  The impact will be the established capability of SEDA in the effective promotion of 
renewable energy development. The outcome will be SEDA’s readiness and capacity to fulfill its 
mandates. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
10.  The outputs will be (i) a renewable energy development road map, (ii) wind potential 
mapping in the selected coastal area, (iii) identification of one concentrated solar power project 
and one wind power plant project, and (iv) training and capacity building support to SEDA on the 
Clean Development Mechanism. 
 
11.  Close coordination will be maintained with stakeholders such as the executing agency, 
other government agencies, and donors during implementation to ensure that the TA takes into 
consideration existing studies, government priorities, strategies, polices, regulations, plans and 
results of projects. Consultants will be required to examine international best practices to be 
used in delivering the TA outputs, and to maintain close working relations with the executing 
agency and ADB. Tripartite meetings among the executing agency, ADB, and the consultants

Manila.

3
will be held periodically to provide guidance to the consultants and to review their reports. 
Workshops and a seminar will be held to collect comments on consultants’ reports and to 
disseminate the main findings of the TA. 
 
12.  To develop the renewable energy development road map, the TA will (i) review the 
existing policies, regulations, strategies, legal framework, and resource potential of renewable 
energy sector in Bangladesh; (ii) identify feasible supporting policy options (including an energy 
tariff, incentive and disincentive measures, legal and regulatory framework, monitoring and 
evaluation  framework,  and  institutional  arrangements)  to  encourage  implementation  of 
renewable energy projects; (iii) review and summarize the results of previous and ongoing 
studies,  initiatives,  and  interventions  undertaken  by  the  government,  sector  entities,  and 
international  development  partners  to  promote  renewable  energy  in  the  power  sector  in 
Bangladesh;  (iv) identify  areas  and  subsectors  suitable  for  renewable  energy  development 
interventions  for  ADB,  ensuring  no  overlapping  with  or  duplication  of  programs  being 
implemented by other development partners; (v) develop stakeholder-accepted selection criteria 
for a list of investment projects and pilot projects that should be ranked according to priority; and 
(vi) develop a renewable energy strategy and action plan for the Bangladesh power sector to be 
implemented over the medium to long term (up to 2020), which shall focus on public policy 
initiatives to facilitate financing and overcoming institutional barriers.  
 
13.  To develop wind potential mapping in the selected coastal area, the TA will (i) review the 
existing data and information on wind potential, especially in the coastal area, and identify the 
location for establishing one or two wind measurement stations in the coastal area; (ii) design, 
procure, and install wind measure stations; (iii) collect and analyze wind data through the wind 
measure equipment for 1 year; and (iv) develop wind potential mapping in the selected coastal 
area. 
 
14.  Based on the wind data collected through wind measurement stations, one wind power 
plant project will be identified. One concentrated solar power project will also be identified based 
on existing solar resource data. 
 
15.  The TA will provide training for about 16 trainees from SEDA. Three review workshops 
will be held—one at the inception stage and two at the interim stages. A seminar will be 
conducted at the draft final report stage to disseminate the TA findings. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
16.  The TA is estimated to cost $600,000 equivalent, of which $500,000 equivalent will be 
financed  on  a  grant  basis  by  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance  Special  Fund  (TASF-IV),  and 
$100,000 will be financed by the government in the form of in-kind contributions such as 
counterpart staff and office accommodation. The detailed cost estimates and financing plan are 
in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
17.  The Power Division under the MPEMR will be the executing agency. The TA will require 
19 person-months (3 international consultants for 10 person-months and 3 national consultants 
for  9  person-months)  of  expert  services.  The  international  consultants  will  include  (i)  a 
renewable  energy  development  specialist,  (ii)  a  Clean  Development  Mechanism  training 
specialist, and (iii) an energy economist. The national consultants will include (i) a renewable 
energy  specialist,  (ii) a  environment  specialist,  and  (iii)  a  social  development  specialist.  A

4   
consulting firm or joint venture and/or consortium will be selected by ADB through quality- and 
cost-based selection procedures in accordance with the Guidelines on the Use of Consultants 
(2010, as amended from time to time). The standard quality–cost ratio of 80:20 and simplified 
technical proposal will be applied. The terms of reference are in Appendix 3. The proceeds of 
the  TA  will  be  disbursed  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance  Disbursement 
Handbook  (2010,  as  amended  from  time  to  time).  Equipment  will  be  procured  using  the 
shopping method in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from 
time to time). 
 
18.  The  duration  of  the  TA  will  be  24  months  (September  2011–August  2013).  The 
international renewable energy development specialist will act as the team leader and facilitate 
communication  with  ADB  and  the  executing  agency.  After  the  commencing  of  consulting 
services, the team leader will be responsible for delivering the expected outputs and progress 
reports to ADB and the executing agency as follows: (i) an inception report focusing on the work 
program within 1 month; (ii) two interim reports within 10 months and 14 months, respectively; 
(iii) a draft final report within 22 months; and (iv) the final report with 24 months. Tripartite 
meetings will be held in Bangladesh to discuss the inception, interim, and draft final reports 
among  the  consultants  the  executing  agency,  and  the  ADB  mission.  Every  6 months,  the 
consultants will prepare a progress report highlighting any achievements and issues that are 
critical for the timely completion of the TA. Within 2 months of the tripartite meeting to discuss 
the draft final report, the team leader will submit a final report in a format acceptable to ADB 
after addressing all comments received from the government and ADB. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Bangladesh for Support for Climate Change Mitigation and Renewable 
Energy Development, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

Appendix 3  9 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.   Introduction 
 
1.  The consultants for the Asian Development Bank (ADB)-financed technical assistance 
(TA)  will  assist  the  Sustainable  Energy  Development  Authority  (SEDA)  to  develop  (i)  a 
renewable energy development road map; (ii) wind potential mapping in the selected coastal 
area; (iii) identification of one concentrated solar power and one wind power plant project; and 
(iv) training and capacity building support to SEDA staff, especially on the Clean Development 
Mechanism (CDM), carbon trading, and related activities. The outcome of the TA will be SEDA’s 
readiness and capability to meet the business projections and fulfill its mandates. The Power 
Division under the Ministry of Power, Energy and Mineral Resources will be the executing 
agency. 
 
2.  ADB  will  recruit  a  consulting  firm  in  accordance  with  its  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of 
Consultants  (2010,  as  amended  from  time  to  time).  The  consulting  firm  will  be  selected 
according to quality- and cost-based selection procedures. The standard quality–cost ratio of 
80:20 and simplified technical proposal will be applied. 
 
3.  The international renewable energy development specialist will act as team leader and 
facilitate communication with ADB, the executing agency, and the government. In particular, the 
team leader will be responsible for delivering the expected outputs and progress reports to ADB. 
 
4.  The duration of the TA will be 24 months (September 2011–August 2013).   
 
B.  Terms of Reference 
 
1.  Renewable Energy Development Specialist and Team Leader (international, 
5 person-months) 
 
5.  The specialist should have a degree, preferably in engineering, with experience in the 
field of renewable energy. The specialist should have at least 8 years work experience in the 
design  and  implementation  of  renewable  energy  programs  and/or  projects  sponsored  by 
national or international financial institutions and development agencies, particularly within some 
of ADB’s developing member countries. 
 
6.  The team leader will be responsible for the overall quality and implementation of the TA 
assignment, providing the required support for the executing agency and reporting to the ADB 
project officer. The team leader will carry out, but not be limited to, the following tasks: 
(i)  review government strategies, policies, legal framework, and regulations on the 
renewable energy sector; 
(ii)  review  the  available  and  relevant  documentation  on  renewable  energy 
development,  including  existing  and  proposed  renewable  energy  projects, 
particularly solar Photovoltaic, concentrated solar power, wind power, biogas, 
and waste power projects;  
(iii)  consult and coordinate with relevant government agencies and other donors, with 
assistance  from  other  team  members,  to  identify  feasible  supporting  policy 
options including an energy tariff, incentive and disincentive measures, legal and 
regulatory  framework,  monitoring  and  evaluation  framework,  and  institutional 
arrangements, to encourage implementation of renewable energy projects;

10  Appendix 3 
 
 
(iv)  identify  areas  and  subsectors  suitable  for  renewable  energy  development 
interventions for ADB, ensuring no overlapping with or duplication of programs 
being implemented by other development partners; 
(v)  develop stakeholder-accepted selection criteria for a list of investment projects 
and pilot projects that should be ranked according to priority; 
(vi)  develop a renewable energy strategy and action plan for the Bangladesh power 
sector, to be implemented in the medium to long term (up to 2020), which shall 
focus on public policy initiatives to facilitate financing and overcoming institutional 
barriers; 
(vii)  using previous satellite-based wind maps by the US National Renewable Energy 
Laboratory and other existing secondhand wind data, select one representative 
site along the coastal area of Bangladesh for reference measurement;  
(viii)  prepare the wind measurement program, including proposing the wind measuring 
equipment, methodology, and assessing quality of existing data to be used for 
the wind mapping; 
(ix)  procure a wind measurement station, and supervise installation and commission 
of such equipment; 
(x)  monitor and collect data over a period of 1 year, categorize and analyze the 
collected data, and complete the wind mapping along the coastal areas; 
(xi)  prepare the operating arrangement, including quality control procedures and data 
management  procedures,  once  the  government  takes  over  the  running  and 
management of the wind measurement station; 
(xii)  based on the resource mapping of solar and 1-year wind data collected through 
the wind measure station, identify one concentrated solar power project and one 
wind power project, taking into consideration other factors such as proximity to 
population, available land, power evacuation, and accessibility; and 
(xiii)  conduct other duties as reasonably requested by ADB. 
 
2.  Renewable Energy Specialist (national, 6 person-months) 
 
7.  The specialist should have a degree, preferably in engineering, with experience in the 
field of clean energy preferably in Bangladesh. The specialist should have at least 6 years work 
experience in the design and implementation of renewable energy programs and/or projects in 
Bangladesh, and be familiar with and knowledgeable about Bangladesh’s energy laws, policies, 
and regulations. 
 
8.  The specialist will support and assist the team leader with the tasks described in para. 6. 
The specialist will carry out, but not be limited to, the following tasks: 
(i)  provide logistical, secretarial, coordination, and research support during meetings, 
reviews, interviews, and workshops; 
(ii)  conduct  secondary  research  for  data  and  information  through  one-to-one 
meetings and/or interviews with the appropriate stakeholders to gather inputs; 
(iii)  assist  the  team  leader  in  supervising  the  procurement,  installation,  and 
commissioning of the wind measurement station; 
(iv)  take the necessary activities to carry out each of the tasks under the terms of 
reference of the international renewable energy development specialist; and 
(v)  perform other functions as may be assigned or delegated by the team leader 
from time to time during the assignment.

Appendix 3  11 
3.  Clean Development Mechanism Training Specialist (international, 3 person-
months) 
 
9  The specialist should have a graduate degree in engineering or energy or environment 
and at least 6 years CDM training experience. 
 
10.  The specialist will carry out, but not be limited to, the following tasks:   
(i)  identify training needs of the selected staff; 
(ii)  prepare CDM training material to suit the identified needs, taking into account the 
nature of eligible CDM projects in Bangladesh; 
(iii)  conduct training sessions, which involve a test or group exercises based on real 
projects; 
(iv)  provide on-the-job training to staff associated with one existing renewable energy 
project—this may involve the entire CDM project registration cycle; and 
(v)  perform other functions as may be assigned or delegated by the team leader 
from time to time during the assignment.  
 
4.  Energy Economist (international, 2 person-months) 
 
11.  The economist should have a degree, preferably in economics and/or engineering, with 
experience in the energy sector. The economist should have a minimum of 6 years work 
experience in some of ADB’s developing member countries. The economist will carry out, but 
not be limited to, the following tasks: 
(i)  undertake economic and financial analysis of the proposed components (pre-
feasibility study on (a) one concentrated solar power project, and (b) one wind 
power project; 
(ii)  evaluate the proposed project’s direct and indirect environmental impacts, and 
carry out economic analysis of these impacts in terms of net present value and 
internal  rates  of  return  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Economic  Evaluation  of 
Environmental Impacts: A Workbook;1 and 
(iii)  perform other functions as may be assigned or delegated by the team leader 
from time to time during the assignment.  
 
5.  Environment Specialist (national, 1.5 person-months) 
 
12.  The  specialist  should  have  minimum  5  years  work  experience  on  environmental 
assessments in the energy sector in Bangladesh, financed by international financial institutions 
(specifically ADB and the World Bank). 
 
13.  The  specialist  should  be  familiar  with  and  knowledgeable  about  Bangladesh’s 
environmental  impact  assessment  framework  and  approval  requirements  related  to 
environmental clearances for power sector investment projects. The specialist should have 
experience  in  preparing  environmental  impact  assessments  and  initial  environmental 
examinations of projects financed by international financial institutions (specifically ADB and the 
World Bank). In accordance with relevant guidelines and policies for environmental assessment, 
the specialist will carry out, but not be limited to, the following tasks: 
(i)  prepare  rapid  environmental  assessment  checklist  and  determine  the 
environmental category for each study;

http://www.adb.org/publications/product.asp?doc=1215

12  Appendix 3 
 
 
(ii)  prepare project descriptions and a summary of environmental issues identified 
for  each  project  component  to  support  the  determination  of  the  project 
environmental categorization; 
(iii)  prepare  initial  environmental  examinations  depending  on  the  subproject 
categorization (environmental category B) assigned by ADB in accordance with 
ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009); and 
(iv)  perform other functions as may be assigned or delegated by the team leader 
from time to time during the assignment.  
 
6.  Social Development Specialist (national, 1.5 person-months) 
14.  The specialist should have minimum 5 years work experience on social development in 
the energy sector in Bangladesh, financed by international financial institutions (specifically ADB 
and the World Bank). 
 
15.  The specialist should be familiar with and knowledgeable about Bangladesh’s national 
laws and policies on land acquisition and involuntary resettlement as well as ADB’s Safeguard 
Policy Statement.  
 
16.  The specialist will carry out, but not be limited to, the following tasks: 
(i)  review  the  required  documentation  in  line  with  ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy 
Statement and relevant Bangladesh regulations; 
(ii)  conduct the necessary surveys to establish baseline socioeconomic data in the 
project areas; 
(iii)  analyze access to electricity, affordability, consumption levels, and consumer 
satisfaction across socioeconomic groups in target project areas; and 
(iv)  perform other functions as may be assigned or delegated by the team leader 
from time to time during the assignment.  
 
C.  Reporting 
 
17.  The team leader will submit to the executing agency and ADB an inception report 
focusing on the work program no later than 1 month after commencing the consultancy services. 
Interim reports will be submitted 10 months and 14 months after the start of the services. A draft 
final report will be submitted 22 months after incorporating all of the deliverables and the 
performance  evaluation  achieved  under  the  TA.  The  final  report  will  be  submitted  within 
2 months after submission of the draft final report. Tripartite meetings will be held in Bangladesh 
to discuss the inception, interim, and draft final reports among the consultants, the executing 
agency and the ADB mission. Every 6 months, the consultants will prepare progress reports 
highlighting any achievements and issues that are critical for the timely completion of the TA. 
Within 2 months of the tripartite meeting to discuss the draft final report, the team leader will 
submit a final report in a format acceptable to ADB after addressing all comments received from 
the government and ADB.
